abstract: Will Keith Olbermann be claimed on waivers? Not tomorrow, but some team with a big need in the middle of the lineup will eventually plug its nose and extend a contract.

lead_paragraph: Adding to the recent wave of artists suing record companies over online royalties, “Weird Al” Yankovic has sued Sony Music Entertainment, saying he is owed more than $5 million. In the suit, filed Friday at United States District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Yankovic says the company underpaid him for videos and other expenses, and also incorrectly counted downloads of his music as “sales” rather than as “licenses,” which pay a higher royalty rate.

headline.main: Digital Notes: ‘Weird Al’ Yankovic Sues Sony for $5 million

lead_paragraph: The long history of newspapers in the City of Brotherly Love took another turn Monday with the sale of parent company of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Daily News to a group of politically connected investors. The price was $55 million, less than half of what the papers sold for just two years earlier. One investor who did not follow through with the deal, writes Amy Chozick, was Ed Rendell, the former Philadelphia mayor and Pennsylvania governor whose participation drew a lot of criticism from inside and outside the papers. “There was enough blowback from reporters and editorial people, because I’m active politically and support candidates and the president, that I decided to step back,” he said, adding the current owners “might ask me my opinion every once in a while.”

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate

lead_paragraph: As I mentioned in my last post, I am going to be writing a series of posts about our expansion into foreign markets. Ever since we began this expansion, I have been asked how often we are solicited for bribes in foreign countries. The funny thing is that while bribery is perceived to be relatively commonplace in international business, it may be more common in this country than people like to think. At least that’s what a former TerraCycle employee who used to work for a major American consumer products company told me.

headline.main: The Micro-Multinational: Our Experience With Bribery in Foreign Markets

The agency, which essentially serves as the government’s back office, managing property, federal purchases and some administrative services, pulled out all the stops when it sent 300 employees to a Las Vegas resort for a conference in 2010 — the bill for the five-day affair totaled $823,000 and included extravagances like luxury hotel suites and $7,000 worth of sushi. But one issue raised in the investigation into the boondoggle hasn’t gotten very much attention: a government contract for running part of the conference that should have gone to a small business seems to have gone to a large company.

abstract: At Trademarkia, “We want to make applying for a trademark as easy as getting a domain name,” said Raj Abhyanker, one of the founders of the start-up with the goal of becoming the world’s biggest law firm.
snippet: At Trademarkia, “We want to make applying for a trademark as easy as getting a domain name,” said Raj Abhyanker, one of the founders of the start-up with the goal of becoming the world’s biggest law firm.
lead_paragraph: Trademarkia is an online search engine that helps small-business owners sift through the more than six million names, slogans and logos that have been trademarked in America since 1870. The Web site, which went live in September 2009, grafts a user-friendly interface onto a colossal database, built with free information provided by the United States Patent and Trademark Office. It also serves as a lure, steering visitors who want to apply for their own trademarks to the law firm of Trademarkia’s co-founder, Raj Abhyanker, and offering other fee-based services such as domain registration, logo design and automated alerts that notify trademark holders when marks similar to their own are filed.

headline.main: A Start-Up Rethinks the Process of Getting a Trademark

abstract: The prediction set off a 14.7 percent decline in the company’s share price on Friday.
snippet: The prediction set off a 14.7 percent decline in the company’s share price on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Talbots, the women’s apparel retailer, said it expected first-quarter sales to fall from the year-earlier period, setting off a 14.7 percent decline in its share price on Friday. Stock in the company fell 46 cents, to $2.67 a share. Talbots said after the close of trading on Thursday that it expected sales for the quarter ending April 30 to fall 9.6 percent from last year to $272 million, as its store base shrinks. Analysts had forecast revenue of $280 million. Talbots swung to a loss for the year ending Jan. 28, as it ceded business to competitors and increased its promotions. Talbots is based in Hingham, Mass.

headline.main: Talbots Forecasts a Decline in First-Quarter Sales

abstract: Share of the company, which operates the Redbox movie-rental kiosks, rose 7 percent on Friday.
snippet: Share of the company, which operates the Redbox movie-rental kiosks, rose 7 percent on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Coinstar, the operator of the Redbox movie-rental kiosks, said in a preliminary report that its first-quarter sales and profit exceeded its February forecast, driven by higher prices. The shares rose $4.47, or 7 percent, to $65.78, on Friday, bringing its gain this year to 44 percent. Profit from continuing operations was $1.62 to $1.66 a share, the company, which is based in Bellevue, Wash., said on Thursday. Sales advanced to $567 million to $569.2 million. Analysts forecast first-quarter profit of 89 cents a share on sales of $538.6 million. Coinstar plans to disclose final results on April 26. Coinstar said it benefited last quarter from lower-than-expected card-processing fees and the popularity of movies like “Moneyball,” “Puss and Boots” and “50/50.”

headline.main: Coinstar Surges on Preliminary Quarterly Results
headline.print_headline: Coinstar Surges On Preliminary Quarterly Results

lead_paragraph: Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of the CBS Corporation, received $69.9 million in 2011 total compensation, 21 percent more than a year earlier, the company said Friday in a regulatory filing. Mr. Moonves’s package included a salary of $3.5 million, a bonus of $27.5 million, stock grants of $8.5 million and options awards of $27.3 million, CBS said. Stock in CBS rose 42 percent last year after the company reduced debt and developed a plan to add $3 billion in revenue, including some through sales of TV shows outside the United States and to online streaming services including Netflix.

headline.main: CBS’s Chief Executive Was Paid $69.9. Million for 2011

lead_paragraph: FACEBOOK makes sharing easy — too easy, some would say. abstract: In May 2010, I wrote about the collapse of a young cancer survivor at what had been a bawdy and rowdy benefit.
snippet: In May 2010, I wrote about the collapse of a young cancer survivor at what had been a bawdy and rowdy benefit.
lead_paragraph: In May 2010, I wrote a blog post called “Are You Doing What You Truly Love?” It was about attending a lively breast cancer benefit, a fashion show with cancer survivors modeling “art” bras. Amid the many women strutting down a long runway to thumping music and yells from an enthusiastic crowd was an under-30 breast cancer patient who collapsed midstride. The chemotherapy had perhaps taken its toll on her heart and she experienced a severe arrhythmia. Basically, her heart stopped. Those of us who were there watched, shocked and saddened, as paramedics worked over her lifeless body. For all of us, it was a jarring reminder of how rapidly things can change and how important it is to make the most of those precious moments between dawn and dusk every day.

headline.main: A Sweet Follow-Up to a Traumatic Evening

Ackman, the hedge fund manager, who is seeking to replace most of the railway’s directors and its senior management through a vote at its annual meeting next month. Fred Green, the chief executive of Canadian Pacific, said the quarterly results were an endorsement of the railway’s management and their operational plans.

abstract: Confronted with evidence of widespread corruption in Mexico, top Wal-Mart executives focused more on damage control than on rooting out wrongdoing, an examination by The New York Times found.
snippet: Confronted with evidence of widespread corruption in Mexico, top Wal-Mart executives focused more on damage control than on rooting out wrongdoing, an examination by The New York Times found.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In September 2005, a senior Wal-Mart lawyer received an alarming e-mail from a former executive at the company’s largest foreign subsidiary, Wal-Mart de Mexico. In the e-mail and follow-up conversations, the former executive described how Wal-Mart de Mexico had orchestrated a campaign of bribery to win market dominance. In its rush to build stores, he said, the company had paid bribes to obtain permits in virtually every corner of the country.

headline.main: Wal-Mart Hushed Up a Vast Mexican Bribery Case

lead_paragraph: Where are all the television viewers? That’s the question network executives are asking, Bill Carter reports, as they study the lower ratings for prime-time programming this spring. Viewing is down across the board, and it’s affecting hit shows like “Modern Family” as well as less popular offerings. Network executives cite good weather and the change to daylight time, but some analysts see more fundamental reasons, including the sporadic scheduling of new episodes and the preference of more viewers to watch shows on a delayed basis, instead of live.

abstract: Laura D’Andrea Tyson, an economist at the University of California, talks about the financial challenges of public universities and the plight of middle-class applicants.

lead_paragraph: Laura D’Andrea Tyson, a contributor to this blog and an economist at the University of California, Berkeley, spoke with Catherine Rampell about the toll that state cutbacks have taken on public universities. Middle-class applicants are most seriously affected, as they may lack the assets or the financial aid to enroll. “It’s part of the broader polarization of the United States,” she says. Part of the solution might be to raise the sticker price for those who can afford it, in order to subsidize others — but such plans run up against state restrictions designed to ensure the university’s public mission.

headline.main: Laura Tyson: The Public University Dilemma

There were a lot of folks to pick from, including David Axelrod, President Obama’s political strategist; the retired general and former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell; and New York’s mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg. He was standing near Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, so an introduction was made.

abstract: Also, caution and relative stagnation at News Corporation, and Discovery Channel crashes a Boeing 727.
snippet: Also, caution and relative stagnation at News Corporation, and Discovery Channel crashes a Boeing 727.
lead_paragraph: The e-book wars added a new alliance, the Microsoft-Barnes & Noble joint venture, DealBook reported on Monday. Microsoft has invested $300 million for a 17.6 percent stake in a new Barnes & Noble’s subsidiary composed of its Nook digital-book business and college-texts units; intriguingly, the deal values the subsidiary at $1.7 billion, much more than Barnes & Noble is worth by itself, as The Wall Street Journal noted. Also, as part of the deal, Microsoft has settled its patent dispute with Barnes & Noble, and there will be a Nook application included in the new Windows 8, which is scheduled to have a release preview in early June.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Microsoft Buys Into the Nook, and Radio’s Shrinking Diversity
